results.title: Guess who's coming to dinner?
results.brief_description: Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy portray the proud parents of a young lady who’s about to bring home the man she wants to marry. They’ve heard he’s handsome and full of career prospects but when they discover that he’s black they find out that they’re not as broadminded as they thought. Sidney Poitier is the son-in-law elect in this examination of prejudice and social manners.

results.title: Guerillas in our midst
results.brief_description: A fascinating exploration of the “art terrorist” activities of the New York Guerrilla Girls, a group of feminist artists who use street theatre and innovative graphics and design to draw attention to the under-representation of women and people of colour in New York art society. Interviews with art collectors, art-house curators and artists reveal the extent to which the tactics of the Guerrilla Girls (who wear gorilla masks to conceal their identity) have forced the established art community in New York to examine their sexist and/or racist assumptions about art. By combining wit, humour and style with politics the Guerrilla Girls are part of a radical street culture, who, along with such artists as Act-Up’s Gran Fury, are altering the graphic landscape of contemporary New York City.

results.title: Guarding Tess
results.creator_credit: Hugh Wilson, Nancy Graham Tanen, Ned Tanen, Channel and Tri-Star Pictures
results.brief_description: Tess Carlisle (Shirley MacLaine) is the widow of a former president of the United States who has become a national treasure. Doug Chesnic (Nicolas Cage) is the secret security agent that is hired to ensure that she stays safe and out of trouble. Doug, accustomed to assignments that involve danger and excitement, dreads his mundane task and he finds Tess patronising, eccentric, rude, demanding and acerbic. Typically within the odd-couple formula, these two adversaries have to reach a truce, which for Doug means trying to maintain his exacting standards despite the unpredictable nature of Tess’ whims. An attempt on Tess’ life and a mystery illness provide narrative developments, but it is mostly the shenanigans and intricacies of the secret service operatives that keep the film interesting. “Guarding Tess” drifts toward melodrama and tends to exude a cloying sentimentality, but it also contains a certain charm due to the performances of Cage and MacLaine. Directed by Hugh Wilson (The First wives club, Dudley do right).

results.title: Guardians of the wild
results.brief_description: Every day, fifty different species of animals disappear from this planet. However, there is hope, as a group of people around the world dedicate their lives to saving the endangered inhabitants of the planet. The animals featured include elephants, cheetahs, the rhinoceros and the wildlife of the Channel Islands.

results.title: Guanaco of Patagonia
results.creator_credit: Megan Epler and William L. Franklin
results.brief_description: A study pf the unique social system of the guanaco, a camel-like animal found in Patagonia, in which family groups aggressively defend fixed territories and expel dependent yearlings.

results.title: Grumpy old man
results.creator_credit: Richard Bailey, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Richard Bailey has nudged and niggled people and he’s had some success, especially on the asbestos issue. A heart attack in 2003 meant that Bailey couldn’t be as active anymore, so he decided to direct his energies elsewhere.

results.title: Gruesome gray monster (Finding colours)
results.brief_description: Designed to sharpen perception and appreciation of colour. Shows the experiences of a young girl who goes to the castle of the gruesome gray monster to recover the colours he has stolen from the world.

results.title: Growth: a study of Johnny and Jimmy. Part 3
results.creator_credit: Warden and Gilbert at Columbia University
results.brief_description: A study of the development of selected activities common to growing infants. Twin boys are selected and the influence of exercise on the development of each motor function at a number of age levels is studied. During the first 22 months Johnny is kept in a crib and then between the 22 to 25 month period was given intensive exercise. The complex interdependence of practice and maturation in development is illustrated. Reel 1: Development of creeping, development of the sitting position, development of erect locomotion, development in the assumption of an erect posture. Reel 2: A lure is suspended beyond the child’s reach in order to appraise his ability to manipulate pedestals so that he can climb up to obtain the object. Reel 3: in some behaviour activities not only attitude but also neuromotor performance are affected by exercise or restriction of funtion. The following are studies: Swimming behaviour and ascending inclines.
